makers.displaydate: born 1948, Havana, Cuba; active Boston, MA
makers.displaymaker: Abelardo Morell, born 1948, Havana, Cuba; active Boston, MA

texts.textentryhtml: Morell has long experimented with the camera obscura, an optical phenomenon in which a small aperture in an otherwise dark space produces an inverted projection of the outside. In 2002, Morell returned to Cuba, from which he fled with his family at the age of fourteen, to continue his series of photographs of camera obscura projections in private rooms. The long exposures necessary due to the minimal available light precluded capturing the movements of people or vehicles, rendering both the interiors and exteriors as deserted spaces. As a meditation on photography, loss, and remembrance, this photograph juxtaposes the projected cityscape of Havana with the glamorous portrait of a woman, balancing the weight of the outside world with the intimate space of the home.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2018," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 77/78 (2017-18)
